these questions. Nevertheless, I thought the DOXA results were interesting, and
worth passing along to you.

Twenty seven per cent of the women polled said simply that they did not know

DOXA and the magazine Olomo summed up this section of the question in this

The article in alamo by the DOXA polling agency then broke down these re¬
sults according to tWe educational background of the Italians polled. I don#t
wish to throw too many figures at you, so perhaps we’ll confine our examination
of this phus© of the question to two groups# But first I should report that the
more education a person had had, the stronger, generally, was his feeling that
scientists who passed atomic secrets to the soviet Union were increasing the
peril of war, rather than contributing to peace.
Among Italians who had gone only to elementary school, or had not attended
school at all, 21 per cent thought scientists delivering atomic secrets to
Russia were working for peace, as aginst 41 per cent who said such scientists
were increasing the risk of war. In this category, 13 per cent said such action
by scientists would have no effect on the chances for peace or war, and 24 per
cent said they did not know how to answer the question.
But when only university graduates were interviewed, the result was striking¬
